FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.10(a).title: Controls for closed systems
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.10(a).text: Validation of systems to ensure accuracy, reliability, consistent intended performance, and the ability to discern invalid or altered records.
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.10(a).summary: Requires software validation processes to guarantee system accuracy, reliability, and the capability to detect invalid or tampered data.

FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.10(b).title: Controls for closed systems
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.10(b).text: The ability to generate accurate and complete copies of records in both human readable and electronic form suitable for inspection, review, and copying by the agency.
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.10(b).summary: The system must be able to export records in both human-readable formats (e.g., PDF, UI display) and electronic formats for inspection.

FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.10(c).title: Controls for closed systems
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.10(c).text: Protection of records to enable their accurate and ready retrieval throughout the records retention period.
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.10(c).summary: Requires technical controls for data storage and backup to ensure records can be retrieved accurately for the duration of the retention period.

FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.10(d).title: Controls for closed systems
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.10(d).text: Limiting system access to authorized individuals.
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.10(d).summary: Implementation of strict access control mechanisms to ensure only authorized users can access the system.

FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.10(e).title: Controls for closed systems
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.10(e).text: Use of secure, computer-generated, time-stamped audit trails to independently record the date and time of operator entries and actions that create, modify, or delete electronic records. Record changes shall not obscure previously recorded information.
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.10(e).summary: Requires an immutable, automated audit log that captures the date, time, and user for all creation, modification, or deletion events without overwriting original data.

FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.10(f).title: Controls for closed systems
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.10(f).text: Use of operational system checks to enforce permitted sequencing of steps and events, as appropriate.
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.10(f).summary: The software must enforce workflow logic to ensure steps occur in the correct, required sequence.

FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.10(g).title: Controls for closed systems
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.10(g).text: Use of authority checks to ensure that only authorized individuals can use the system, electronically sign a record, access the operation or computer system input or output device, alter a record, or perform the operation at hand.
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.10(g).summary: Requires granular authorization checks (Role-Based Access Control) to ensure users only perform actions or sign records they are specifically permitted to.

FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.10(h).title: Controls for closed systems
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.10(h).text: Use of device (e.g., terminal) checks to determine, as appropriate, the validity of the source of data input or operational instruction.
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.10(h).summary: System must verify that data input comes from valid devices or terminals, relevant for IoT or specific hardware integrations.

FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.10(k).title: Controls for closed systems
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.10(k).text: Use of appropriate controls over systems documentation including: (1) Adequate controls over the distribution of, access to, and use of documentation for system operation and maintenance. (2) Revision and change control procedures to maintain an audit trail that documents time-sequenced development and modification of systems documentation.
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.10(k).summary: Requires version control and access restrictions for system documentation and configuration, including audit trails for changes.

FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.30.title: Controls for open systems
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.30.text: Persons who use open systems to create, modify, maintain, or transmit electronic records shall employ procedures and controls designed to ensure the authenticity, integrity, and, as appropriate, the confidentiality of electronic records from the point of their creation to the point of their receipt. Such procedures and controls shall include those identified in § 11.10, as appropriate, and additional measures such as document encryption and use of appropriate digital signature standards to ensure, as necessary under the circumstances, record authenticity, integrity, and confidentiality.
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.30.summary: For systems connected to external networks (open systems), encryption and digital signature standards must be used to ensure data integrity and confidentiality during transmission.

FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.50(a).title: Signature manifestations
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.50(a).text: Signed electronic records shall contain information associated with the signing that clearly indicates all of the following: (1) The printed name of the signer; (2) The date and time when the signature was executed; and (3) The meaning (such as review, approval, responsibility, or authorship) associated with the signature.
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.50(a).summary: Electronic signatures must explicitly store and display the signer's name, timestamp, and the specific reason for the signature.

FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.50(b).title: Signature manifestations
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.50(b).text: The items identified in paragraphs (a)(1), (a)(2), and (a)(3) of this section shall be subject to the same controls as for electronic records and shall be included as part of any human readable form of the electronic record (such as electronic display or printout).
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.50(b).summary: Signature details (name, time, meaning) must be visible on all human-readable views (screens, PDFs) and protected with the same security as the record itself.

FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.70.title: Signature/record linking
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.70.text: Electronic signatures and handwritten signatures executed to electronic records shall be linked to their respective electronic records to ensure that the signatures cannot be excised, copied, or otherwise transferred to falsify an electronic record by ordinary means.
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.70.summary: Cryptographic or logical linking must bind the signature to the specific record, preventing the signature from being copied or moved to another document.

FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.100(a).title: General requirements
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.100(a).text: Each electronic signature shall be unique to one individual and shall not be reused by, or reassigned to, anyone else.
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.100(a).summary: System must ensure unique identifiers for every user; user IDs cannot be recycled or reassigned to different individuals.

FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.200(a)(1).title: Electronic signature components and controls
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.200(a)(1).text: Electronic signatures that are not based upon biometrics shall: (1) Employ at least two distinct identification components such as an identification code and password.
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.200(a)(1).summary: Non-biometric signatures must use Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) or at minimum two distinct components (e.g., ID and Password).

FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.200(a)(1)(i).title: Electronic signature components and controls
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.200(a)(1)(i).text: When an individual executes a series of signings during a single, continuous period of controlled system access, the first signing shall be executed using all electronic signature components; subsequent signings shall be executed using at least one electronic signature component that is only executable by, and designed to be used only by, the individual.
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.200(a)(1)(i).summary: In a continuous session, the first signature requires full authentication (e.g., ID+Password), while subsequent signatures in that session require at least one component (e.g., Password only).

FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.200(a)(1)(ii).title: Electronic signature components and controls
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.200(a)(1)(ii).text: When an individual executes one or more signings not performed during a single, continuous period of controlled system access, each signing shall be executed using all of the electronic signature components.
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.200(a)(1)(ii).summary: If a session is interrupted or non-continuous, every signature action requires re-entry of all authentication components (e.g., ID+Password).

FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.200(b).title: Electronic signature components and controls
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.200(b).text: Electronic signatures based upon biometrics shall be designed to ensure that they cannot be used by anyone other than their genuine owners.
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.200(b).summary: Biometric authentication systems must have high fidelity to prevent false positives or spoofing.

FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.300(a).title: Controls for identification codes/passwords
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.300(a).text: Maintaining the uniqueness of each combined identification code and password, such that no two individuals have the same combination of identification code and password.
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.300(a).summary: The system must enforce unique ID/password combinations to prevent credential collisions.

FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.300(b).title: Controls for identification codes/passwords
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.300(b).text: Ensuring that identification code and password issuances are periodically checked, recalled, or revised (e.g., to cover such events as password aging).
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.300(b).summary: The system must support password expiration policies and forced revisions (password aging).

FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.300(d).title: Controls for identification codes/passwords
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.300(d).text: Following loss management procedures to electronically deauthorize lost, stolen, missing, or otherwise potentially compromised tokens, cards, and other devices that bear or generate identification code or password information.
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.300(d).summary: System must provide the capability to immediately revoke or deauthorize compromised credentials, tokens, or cards.

FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.300(e).title: Controls for identification codes/passwords
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.300(e).text: Use of transaction safeguards to prevent unauthorized use of passwords and/or identification codes, and to detect and report in an immediate and urgent manner any attempts at their unauthorized use to the system security unit, and, as appropriate, to organizational management.
FDA (21 CFR Part 11) 11.300(e).summary: Implementation of intrusion detection, account lockout policies, and immediate alerting for failed authentication attempts or unauthorized access patterns.

HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.source: HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR Part 164)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.title: Information system activity review (Required)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.text: Implement procedures to regularly review records of information system activity, such as audit logs, access reports, and security incident tracking reports.
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.summary: Software must generate and maintain audit logs and access reports to facilitate regular security reviews of system activity.

HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.source: HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR Part 164)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.title: Isolating health care clearinghouse functions (Required)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.text: If a health care clearinghouse is part of a larger organization, the clearinghouse must implement policies and procedures that protect the electronic protected health information of the clearinghouse from unauthorized access by the larger organization.
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.summary: Requires logical segmentation or isolation of software systems handling ePHI from other organizational systems to prevent unauthorized access.

HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.source: HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR Part 164)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.title: Protection from malicious software (Addressable)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.text: Procedures for guarding against, detecting, and reporting malicious software.
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.summary: Software environments must include mechanisms (such as anti-malware integration) to detect, block, and report malicious software.

HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.source: HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR Part 164)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.title: Log-in monitoring (Addressable)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.text: Procedures for monitoring log-in attempts and reporting discrepancies.
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.summary: The system must track login attempts, identifying and alerting on discrepancies or suspicious activities (e.g., brute force attacks).

HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.source: HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR Part 164)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.title: Password management (Addressable)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.text: Procedures for creating, changing, and safeguarding passwords.
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.summary: Implement system controls for password complexity, rotation, secure storage (hashing/salting), and safe modification workflows.

HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.source: HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR Part 164)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.title: Data backup plan (Required)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.text: Establish and implement procedures to create and maintain retrievable exact copies of electronic protected health information.
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.summary: Software systems must include automated backup capabilities to ensure ePHI is copied and retrievable.

HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.source: HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR Part 164)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.title: Device and media controls - Disposal (Required)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.text: Implement policies and procedures to address the final disposition of electronic protected health information, and/or the hardware or electronic media on which it is stored.
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.summary: Requires software capabilities to securely delete or sanitize data (sanitization) when ePHI or storage media is decommissioned.

HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.source: HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR Part 164)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.title: Device and media controls - Media re-use (Required)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.text: Implement procedures for removal of electronic protected health information from electronic media before the media are made available for re-use.
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.summary: Systems must provide mechanisms to securely wipe or overwrite ePHI from storage media prior to reallocation.

HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.source: HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR Part 164)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.title: Access control (Required)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.text: Implement technical policies and procedures for electronic information systems that maintain electronic protected health information to allow access only to those persons or software programs that have been granted access rights as specified in § 164.308(a)(4).
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.summary: Implement robust technical access controls (RBAC/ABAC) to restrict access to ePHI solely to authorized users and services.

HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.source: HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR Part 164)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.title: Unique user identification (Required)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.text: Assign a unique name and/or number for identifying and tracking user identity.
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.summary: The system must ensure every user is assigned a unique identifier to track activity and identity.

HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.source: HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR Part 164)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.title: Emergency access procedure (Required)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.text: Establish (and implement as needed) procedures for obtaining necessary electronic protected health information during an emergency.
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.summary: Software must support emergency access mechanisms ('break-glass' features) to allow authorized access to critical data during emergencies.

HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.source: HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR Part 164)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.title: Automatic logoff (Addressable)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.text: Implement electronic procedures that terminate an electronic session after a predetermined time of inactivity.
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.summary: The application must enforce automatic session termination or locking after a configurable period of user inactivity.

HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.source: HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR Part 164)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.title: Encryption and decryption (Addressable)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.text: Implement a mechanism to encrypt and decrypt electronic protected health information.
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.summary: Implement encryption for ePHI at rest and mechanisms for decryption by authorized processes.

HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.source: HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR Part 164)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.title: Audit controls (Required)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.text: Implement hardware, software, and/or procedural mechanisms that record and examine activity in information systems that contain or use electronic protected health information.
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.summary: Implement comprehensive audit logging to record read, write, and modification activities on ePHI.

HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.source: HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR Part 164)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.title: Integrity (Required)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.text: Implement policies and procedures to protect electronic protected health information from improper alteration or destruction.
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.summary: Implement technical controls (e.g., checksums, versioning, access restrictions) to prevent unauthorized modification or deletion of data.

HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.source: HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR Part 164)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.title: Mechanism to authenticate electronic protected health information (Addressable)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.text: Implement electronic mechanisms to corroborate that electronic protected health information has not been altered or destroyed in an unauthorized manner.
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.summary: Use hashing, digital signatures, or checksums to verify that ePHI has not been tampered with.

HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.source: HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR Part 164)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.title: Person or entity authentication (Required)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.text: Implement procedures to verify that a person or entity seeking access to electronic protected health information is the one claimed.
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.summary: Implement authentication protocols (MFA, certificates, passwords) to verify the identity of users or systems requesting access.

HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.source: HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR Part 164)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.title: Transmission security (Required)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.text: Implement technical security measures to guard against unauthorized access to electronic protected health information that is being transmitted over an electronic communications network.
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.summary: Ensure technical measures (like TLS/SSL) are in place to secure ePHI during transmission over networks.

HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.source: HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR Part 164)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.title: Transmission security - Integrity controls (Addressable)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.text: Implement security measures to ensure that electronically transmitted electronic protected health information is not improperly modified without detection until disposed of.
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.summary: Implement message integrity checks (HMAC, digital signatures) for data in transit to detect unauthorized modification.

HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.source: HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR Part 164)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.title: Transmission security - Encryption (Addressable)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.text: Implement a mechanism to encrypt electronic protected health information whenever deemed appropriate.
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.summary: Encrypt ePHI during transmission using secure protocols (e.g., HTTPS, SFTP, VPN).

HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.source: HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR Part 164)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.title: De-identification of protected health information (Safe Harbor)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.text: The following identifiers of the individual or of relatives, employers, or household members of the individual, are removed: (A) Names; (B) All geographic subdivisions smaller than a State... (C) All elements of dates (except year)... (G) Social security numbers; (H) Medical record numbers... (Q) Full face photographic images...
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.summary: Software attempting to de-identify data for secondary use must implement algorithms to strip or mask the 18 specific identifiers listed.

HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.source: HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR Part 164)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.title: Form of access requested (Electronic)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.text: If the protected health information that is the subject of a request for access is maintained in one or more designated record sets electronically and if the individual requests an electronic copy of such information, the covered entity must provide the individual with access to the protected health information in the electronic form and format requested by the individual, if it is readily producible in such form and format; or, if not, in a readable electronic form and format as agreed to by the covered entity and the individual.
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.summary: The system must support the export of ePHI in standard electronic formats to fulfill patient access requests.

HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.source: HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR Part 164)
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.title: Right to an accounting of disclosures
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.text: An individual has a right to receive an accounting of disclosures of protected health information made by a covered entity in the six years prior to the date on which the accounting is requested...
HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules (45 CFR.summary: Software must maintain a long-term log (6 years) of specific data disclosures to generate accounting reports for individuals.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.5.12.title: Classification of information
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.5.12.text: Information shall be classified according to the information security needs of the organization based on confidentiality, integrity, availability and relevant interested party requirements.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.5.12.summary: Requires the implementation of metadata tagging or labeling capabilities within information systems to handle data classification levels.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.5.14.title: Information transfer
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.5.14.text: Information transfer rules, procedures, or agreements shall be in place for all types of transfer facilities within the organization and between the organization and other parties.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.5.14.summary: Requires secure protocols (e.g., TLS, SFTP) and encryption mechanisms for data in transit between internal and external systems.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.5.15.title: Access control
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.5.15.text: Rules to control physical and logical access to information and other associated assets shall be established and implemented based on business and information security requirements.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.5.15.summary: Requires the implementation of logical access control mechanisms (authentication and authorization gates) for information systems.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.5.16.title: Identity management
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.5.16.text: The full life cycle of identities shall be managed.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.5.16.summary: Requires software processes for provisioning, modifying, and de-provisioning user identities and accounts.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.5.17.title: Authentication information
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.5.17.text: Allocation and management of authentication information shall be controlled by a management process, including advising personnel on appropriate handling of authentication information.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.5.17.summary: Requires technical controls for managing credentials, such as password complexity enforcement, rotation, and secure storage (hashing/salting).

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.5.18.title: Access rights
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.5.18.text: Access rights to information and other associated assets shall be provisioned, reviewed, modified and removed in accordance with the organization’s topic-specific policy on and rules for access control.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.5.18.summary: Requires systems to support granular permission assignment, modification, and revocation (RBAC/ABAC).

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.5.23.title: Information security for use of cloud services
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.5.23.text: Processes for acquisition, use, management and exit from cloud services shall be established in accordance with the organization’s information security requirements.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.5.23.summary: Requires secure configuration, access management, and segregation of data within cloud service environments.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.5.28.title: Collection of evidence
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.5.28.text: The organization shall establish and implement procedures for the identification, collection, acquisition and preservation of evidence related to information security events.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.5.28.summary: Requires logging and data retention capabilities that ensure integrity for forensic analysis during incident response.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.5.30.title: ICT readiness for business continuity
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.5.30.text: ICT readiness shall be planned, implemented, maintained and tested based on business continuity objectives and ICT continuity requirements.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.5.30.summary: Requires high availability, failover mechanisms, and redundancy configurations in software architecture to support business continuity.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.5.33.title: Protection of records
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.5.33.text: Records shall be protected from loss, destruction, falsification, unauthorized access and unauthorized release.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.5.33.summary: Requires mechanisms to ensure data integrity and immutability for critical records and logs.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.5.34.title: Privacy and protection of personal identifiable information (PII)
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.5.34.text: The organization shall identify and meet the requirements regarding the preservation of privacy and protection of PII according to applicable laws and regulations and contractual requirements.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.5.34.summary: Requires technical controls such as encryption, anonymization, and strict access controls for PII data.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.6.7.title: Remote working
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.6.7.text: Security measures shall be implemented when personnel are working remotely to protect information accessed, processed or stored outside the organization’s premises.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.6.7.summary: Requires secure remote access technologies (VPN, MFA) and endpoint security controls.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.7.7.title: Clear desk and clear screen
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.7.7.text: Clear desk rules for papers and removable storage media and clear screen rules for information processing facilities shall be defined and appropriately enforced.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.7.7.summary: Requires implementation of automatic session locking and screen timeouts for user endpoints.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.7.14.title: Secure disposal or re-use of equipment
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.7.14.text: Items of equipment containing storage media shall be verified to ensure that any sensitive data and licensed software has been removed or securely overwritten prior to disposal or re-use.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.7.14.summary: Requires software tools or utilities to securely wipe or overwrite storage media to prevent data recovery.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.1.title: User end point devices
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.1.text: Information stored on, processed by or accessible via user end point devices shall be protected.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.1.summary: Requires endpoint protection software, disk encryption, and configuration management on user devices.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.2.title: Privileged access rights
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.2.text: The allocation and use of privileged access rights shall be restricted and managed.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.2.summary: Requires strict enforcement of principle of least privilege and Privileged Access Management (PAM) controls.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.3.title: Information access restriction
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.3.text: Access to information and other associated assets shall be restricted in accordance with the established topic-specific policy on access control.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.3.summary: Requires technical implementation of Access Control Lists (ACLs) and network segmentation to restrict data access.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.4.title: Access to source code
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.4.text: Read and write access to source code, development tools and software libraries shall be appropriately managed.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.4.summary: Requires version control system permissions and access controls for code repositories.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.5.title: Secure authentication
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.5.text: Secure authentication technologies and procedures shall be implemented based on information access restrictions and the topic-specific policy on access control.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.5.summary: Requires implementation of Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) and secure login protocols.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.6.title: Capacity management
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.6.text: The use of resources shall be monitored and adjusted in line with current and expected capacity requirements.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.6.summary: Requires system monitoring tools to track resource usage and enable scaling or alerting.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.7.title: Protection against malware
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.7.text: Protection against malware shall be implemented and supported by appropriate user awareness.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.7.summary: Requires implementation of anti-malware software, EDR solutions, and automated scanning.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.8.title: Management of technical vulnerabilities
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.8.text: Information about technical vulnerabilities of information systems in use shall be obtained, the organization’s exposure to such vulnerabilities shall be evaluated and appropriate measures shall be taken.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.8.summary: Requires automated vulnerability scanning and patch management systems.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.9.title: Configuration management
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.9.text: Configurations, including security configurations, of hardware, software, services and networks shall be established, documented, implemented, monitored and reviewed.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.9.summary: Requires configuration management tools to enforce security baselines and detect drift.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.10.title: Information deletion
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.10.text: Information stored in information systems, devices or in any other storage media shall be deleted when no longer required.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.10.summary: Requires automated data retention policies and secure deletion mechanisms within applications.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.11.title: Data masking
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.11.text: Data masking shall be used in accordance with the organization’s topic-specific policy on access control and other related topic-specific policies, and business requirements, taking applicable legislation into consideration.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.11.summary: Requires implementation of dynamic masking, pseudonymization, or redaction of sensitive data in views and logs.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.12.title: Data leakage prevention
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.12.text: Data leakage prevention measures shall be applied to systems, networks and any other devices that process, store or transmit sensitive information.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.12.summary: Requires DLP solutions to monitor and block unauthorized exfiltration of sensitive data.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.13.title: Information backup
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.13.text: Backup copies of information, software and systems shall be maintained and regularly tested in accordance with the agreed topic-specific policy on backup.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.13.summary: Requires automated backup solutions and restoration testing capabilities.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.14.title: Redundancy of information processing facilities
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.14.text: Information processing facilities shall be implemented with redundancy sufficient to meet availability requirements.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.14.summary: Requires failover clusters, load balancing, and redundant infrastructure components.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.15.title: Logging
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.15.text: Logs that record activities, exceptions, faults and other relevant events shall be produced, stored, protected and analysed.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.15.summary: Requires comprehensive audit logging, centralized log storage, and protection against log tampering.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.16.title: Monitoring activities
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.16.text: Networks, systems and applications shall be monitored for anomalous behaviour and appropriate actions taken to evaluate potential information security incidents.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.16.summary: Requires monitoring tools (IDS/IPS/SIEM) to detect and alert on anomalous security events.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.17.title: Clock synchronization
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.17.text: The clocks of information processing systems used by the organization shall be synchronized to approved time sources.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.17.summary: Requires configuration of NTP (Network Time Protocol) to ensure consistent timestamps across all systems.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.18.title: Use of privileged utility programs
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.18.text: The use of utility programs that can be capable of overriding system and application controls shall be restricted and tightly controlled.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.18.summary: Requires restrictions on the installation and execution of powerful system utilities and debuggers.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.19.title: Installation of software on operational systems
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.19.text: Procedures and measures shall be implemented to securely manage software installation on operational systems.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.19.summary: Requires mechanisms like allowlisting or software restriction policies to control software installation.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.20.title: Networks security
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.20.text: Networks and network devices shall be secured, managed and controlled to protect information in systems and applications.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.20.summary: Requires firewall configurations, secure routing, and network device hardening.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.21.title: Security of network services
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.21.text: Security mechanisms, service levels and service requirements of network services shall be identified, implemented and monitored.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.21.summary: Requires verification and monitoring of security controls within network services (e.g., DNSSEC, VPN).

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.22.title: Segregation of networks
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.22.text: Groups of information services, users and information systems shall be segregated in the organization’s networks.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.22.summary: Requires network separation using VLANs, subnets, or virtual networks to isolate assets.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.23.title: Web filtering
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.23.text: Access to external websites shall be managed to reduce exposure to malicious content.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.23.summary: Requires implementation of web proxies, DNS filtering, or URL blocking tools.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.24.title: Use of cryptography
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.24.text: Rules for the effective use of cryptography, including cryptographic key management, shall be defined and implemented.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.24.summary: Requires correct implementation of encryption algorithms and secure key management lifecycles.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.25.title: Secure development life cycle
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.25.text: Rules for the secure development of software and systems shall be established and applied.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.25.summary: Requires integration of security gates and tools (SAST/DAST) into the software development lifecycle.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.26.title: Application security requirements
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.26.text: Information security requirements shall be identified, specified and approved when developing or acquiring applications.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.26.summary: Requires defining non-functional security requirements (NFRs) for applications.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.27.title: Secure system architecture and engineering principles
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.27.text: Principles for engineering secure systems shall be established, documented, maintained and applied to any information system development activities.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.27.summary: Requires strict adherence to secure design patterns (e.g., defense in depth, fail secure) in system architecture.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.28.title: Secure coding
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.28.text: Secure coding principles shall be applied to software development.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.28.summary: Requires adherence to secure coding standards (e.g., OWASP) to prevent common vulnerabilities like SQLi and XSS.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.29.title: Security testing in development and acceptance
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.29.text: Security testing processes shall be defined and implemented in the development life cycle.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.29.summary: Requires execution of security tests (penetration testing, scanning) prior to production deployment.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.31.title: Separation of development, test and production environments
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.31.text: Development, testing and production environments shall be separated and secured.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.31.summary: Requires logical and network isolation between dev, test, and production environments.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.32.title: Change management
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.32.text: Changes to information processing facilities and information systems shall be subject to change management procedures.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.32.summary: Requires automated CI/CD pipelines and gated check-ins to control software changes.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.33.title: Test information
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.33.text: Test information shall be appropriately selected, protected and managed.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.33.summary: Requires use of sanitized or synthetic data in testing environments; prohibits production data use without masking.

ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.34.title: Protection of information systems during audit testing
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.34.text: Audit tests and other assurance activities involving assessment of operational systems shall be planned and agreed between the tester and appropriate management.
ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.34.summary: Requires systems to support read-only access or isolated clones for auditing to prevent operational disruption.
